docs.lead_paragraph: On a snowy January evening, in the kitchen of a powder blue colonial at the end of a still, winding block in the suburbs of Washington, Titia and her husband, Kaprr, two immigrants from Sierra Leone, enjoyed a rare family evening together. Their youngest children, a giddy pair of elementary-schoolers, rushed in and out of the room. Their teenage daughter chattered about her ''cheerleading skills.'' Even the 17-year-old Deen made an appearance, slouching up from the basement to pick at leftovers from dinner. It seemed a storybook image of the American immigrant dream. But across the room, in low voices so the kids couldn't hear, Kaprr spoke about the circumstances threatening to break up his family. Kaprr and Titia have been living in the United States for 13 years. By the time they moved into this house five years ago, they had legal status, steady jobs, a growing family, night-school degrees well under way and a mortgage. Despite appearances, though, Kaprr and Titia are not Americans, or even on a certain path to citizenship. Rather, they are among at least 2,700 Sierra Leoneans living and working legally across the United States who face deportation unless they leave the country by May 3.

headline.main: The Way We Live Now: 5-2-04: Phenomenon; Exit Date

docs.abstract: Douglas McGray article on family of illegal immigrants from Sierra Leone who face deportation; in 1997, US granted all Sierra Leoneans living within its borders temporary protection status, designed to protect refugees who cannot benefit from asylum laws; status grants right to work and live in US legally but not citizenship and is renewable annually depending on crisis in country of origin; temporary status is ending for Sierra Leonians and, with three children born in US who are citizens, family is mired in complex and uncertain situation; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR longer than most doctors in New Jersey would care to remember, patients have been cautioned by family, friends -- and sometimes physicians themselves -- that if surgery or some other procedure is called for, find a doctor in the city and don't leave it up to someone who could not work his way out of the medical wasteland that is New Jersey. More and more, however, patients have another choice rather than travel back and forth to New York or Philadelphia -- complicating a difficult or even-life-threatening condition. In strip malls and along suburban pikes, high-tech specialized medical clinics are popping up like fast-food drive-ins and 7-Elevens. Pull into the parking lot and leave with a new knee. Stay overnight, find out why you can't sleep. Even chemotherapy has gone suburban casual.

headline.main: The Maturing Of New Jersey's Health Network

Many identified with the couple seeking medical insurance, and others were moved by Lynn Redgrave's journal.

docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S property tax season again - when homeowners in Westchester find out how much the various components of their property tax bill have gone up. The writing has been on the wall for months. Everyone knows that the costs of health insurance, pensions, labor contracts and unfinanced state mandates have systematically driven up the expenses of state, county, local government and school district budgets everywhere. No one has been spared. In the meantime, local politicians and school boards are busy pointing the finger at somebody else or simply ducking the issue. Everyone agrees that Westchester County - with the highest average property tax per household in New York State -- burdens its homeowners disproportionately. What very few people know is that the county's residents are trapped in one of the most confusing, complex and seemingly arbitrary property tax systems imaginable.
docs.abstract: Investment manager Franklin J Chu Soapbox essay on Westchester County's property tax system, which he contends is confusing, complex and seemingly arbitrary; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ON a Friday last May, not far from the blaze of Times Square lights, Carol and Daniel Giordano, with their daughter, Dana, 12, were waiting to cross Seventh Avenue when Dana slumped to the ground in a seizure. Mr. Giordano flagged a police car, and a passing ambulance took her to New York Presbyterian Hospital. For the next five weeks, the family was camped out there as Dana endured high blood pressure, fevers and an induced coma to stop her seizures.

headline.main: Illness Strikes, and Insurance Falls Short

docs.abstract: Home Front column on financial stress of families facing extraordinary medical costs that even good insurance plans do not cover entirely; Carol and Daniel Giordano explain struggle to pay for treatment of daughter's chronic seizures; their photo; help from New York Medicaid's Care at Home waiver program explained (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Elderly and disabled Americans will be able to sign up starting Monday for the first tangible benefit to emerge from the Medicare prescription drug program approved by Congress last year. It is a drug discount card that is supposed to reduce drug prices by 10 to 25 percent for cardholders as a stopgap measure until the full prescription drug benefit kicks in on Jan. 1, 2006. How great the savings will turn out to be in practice is a matter of conjecture, but the cards will at least provide a projected seven million beneficiaries with group purchasing power like that long marshaled by big health insurance plans. The greatest benefits will go to those on low incomes (below about $12,500 for individuals and $16,800 for couples). They will get a $600 annual subsidy plus a discount on purchases above that. The value of the cards to people with higher incomes is less clear. One recent analysis by Harvard researchers estimated that the average beneficiary might get a 17 percent reduction from standard retail prices, thus saving some $240 on a typical annual drug bill of $1,400. That is some help, but hardly enough for people struggling to pay the high cost of their medicines. Of course, some elderly Americans already get senior discounts at their drugstores or buy drugs through Internet pharmacies with discounts that look comparable to those that will be available with the new cards, so the gains for them may be negligible.
docs.abstract: Editorial contends that Medicare drug discount cards that Americans will be able to sign up for starting May 3 are too weak a weapon to have much impact on upward rise of prescription drug costs; holds that they simply offer discount from prices that seem out of control

docs.lead_paragraph: Butch Krichman was the kind of obsessed child who made a ball field his home from morning until night. If he couldn't find a team to play with in his Jersey Shore universe, he'd draw a box with an X on a concrete wall, measure off 45 feet and hurl a rubber ball against the wall just to hear its comforting thump. ''I knew nothing else but the game,'' he said. ''I wasn't good at anything else.''

headline.main: Keeping a Full Plate; Calling Games All Day, an Iron Man Among Umpires

docs.abstract: New York City baseball umpire Butch Krichman, who calls amateur adult, Little League and public school games, has umpired close to 8,000 games and, unlike most of his peers, has been able to work fulltime as umpire; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A new Medicare Web site comparing prescription drug prices is full of inaccurate, erroneous information, sponsors of drug discount cards said on Friday, just hours after the site was unveiled by the Bush administration. Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, had said the Web site would shine a light on some of the biggest secrets in the health care industry, allowing Medicare beneficiaries to penetrate the mysteries of drug pricing.
docs.abstract: Bush administration unveils Medicare Web site comparing prescription drug prices, but sponsors of drug discount cards say site is full of inaccurate information; say inaccuracies are adding to confusion surrounding discount cards and new Medicare law that added prescription drug coverage; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: New York State regulators are studying the potential impact of the proposed merger between UnitedHealth Group and Oxford Health Plans, and the American Medical Association is calling for federal regulators to review the combination's effect on competition. UnitedHealth, one of the nation's largest health insurers, with more than 20 million customers nationwide, agreed this week to buy Oxford for $4.7 billion as way of gaining a greater presence in the metropolitan New York City area. Insurers like UnitedHealth, which currently has about 2.5 million customers in the New York region, are increasingly looking toward such acquisitions as a way of adding customers.

headline.main: Merger of 2 Health Plans Getting Regulatory Review

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A2-8 Ceding Security in Falluja To Former Iraqi General The majority of U.S. Marines in Falluja withdrew and began handing over control to a former Iraqi general and the men under his command. Even as efforts to restore calm were under way, skirmishes were reported and a suicide bomber killed two marines. A1
